page.title: 03WILTSHIRE LEGENDS & FOLKLORE
page.content: Many legends and stories are told about the chalk downs, and it is said that there is even a possibility that our most traditional game - that of English Cricket - could have originated on the chalk downs. The wicket - or wicket gate at the entrance to a sheep-fold - and the local shepherds who used to practise defending it with their crooks. Attackers would bowl stones at the defender who would hit them away with the curve of their crooks. Old Wiltshire villagers were convinced that hedgehogs sucked milk from cows lying in the meadows. They also swore that they visited orchards and carried off apples on their spines. Should a magpie perch on a roof, it signified that the roof was sound: No tree used by a magpie would ever be uprooted by the wind.
